images.title: John Haynes / Afon Dyfrdwy from the graveyard of St. Hilary Erbistock Ford
images.caption: Afon Dyfrdwy from the graveyard of St. Hilary Erbistock Ford. What a delightful spot this is, taken from the bank above the river in the graveyard of the parish church looking down towards the famous Boat Inn. There used to be a ferry at this point, hence the name of the inn. A long vanished ford is also there somewhere.

images.title: Eirian Evans / The Boat Inn, Erbistock
images.caption: The Boat Inn, Erbistock. Situated alongside the river Dee, it's at the end of a long, single track road which passes the church and leads to a dead end.

images.caption: Through the Trees. The weir at Erbistock Mill. Salmon can be seen jumping here.

images.title: John Haynes / Afon Dyfrdwy hidden deep in the trees at Sodylt Ford
images.caption: Afon Dyfrdwy hidden deep in the trees at Sodylt Ford. The ford is long gone but the name remains. The contrast between the wide open field of maize stubble on the south bank and the steep wooded bank of the north is very clear from this angle. This view is just west of the village.

description: This pretty village in Wrexham County lies in a delightful spot on the River Dee. It's a pleasant place for a walk with fine scenery and two historic local pubs for some refreshment afterwards. This circular walk starts from the 17th century Boat Inn and takes you along the river before heading into the surrounding woodland and countryside. On the way you will also pass the weir at Erbistock Mill and the Grade II listed St Hilary's church. The area around the church is particularly lovely with peaceful riverside trails and evidence of the old ferry which once took passengers to the opposite side. The Maelor Way and the Wat's Dyke Way Heritage Trail run through the village. These long distance walking trails are a great way of further exploring the area.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Boat Inn is a splendid old riverside inn where you can relax after your exercise. The building dates back to the 1600s and is known for its association with the old ferry and as part of the collection of buildings which form the Erbistock conservation area. They serve high quality dishes which you can enjoy in the lovely outdoor seating area overlooking the river. Postcode for sat navs is LL13 0DL.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The riverside and woodland trails make for a fine dog walk. The Boat Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly.
